list: This survey provides real-time information during the coronavirus (COVID-19) pandemic to help inform the UK response.
Your response helps ensure your business, and businesses like yours, are represented.
View the latest publication produced from this survey

content.description: Thank you for completing this survey at this challenging time.

list: Information should relate to the UK.
We will treat your information securely and confidentially.
This survey is refreshed every two weeks.
To avoid losing data and to help us provide real-time information please submit by the return by date, or at the latest before the next fortnightly survey goes live.
You can save a copy of your answers as a pdf at the end of this questionnaire using the 'print' button.

content.description: This section asks for general information on the business's trading status.
This section asks for information about how the coronavirus (COVID-19) pandemic may have affected:

list: turnover in the last two weeks and expectations for the next two weeks
profits in the last two weeks

content.description: This section asks for information about the business's exporting and importing activities.
This section asks for information about:

list: the availability of materials, goods and services within the UK
use of UK logistics services

questions.question: Prices of materials, goods and services

content.description: This section asks for information on any changes to the prices and demand of goods and services bought or sold by the business in the last two weeks.
This section asks for information about the business's stock levels and capital expenditure.

questions.question: Preparedness for the end of the EU transition period

content.description: This section asks for information about your preparedness for the end of the EU transition period, and any changes to supply chains, as a result.

The transition period is when the UK is no longer a member of the EU but continues to be subject to EU rules and remains a member of the single market and customs union. This period ends on 31 December 2020. For further information about the transition go to Gov.uk/transition
We are asking these questions to understand how the end of the EU transition period may affect trade and supply chain activity in the UK and overseas.
This section asks for information about:

list: support the business may have applied for or received from the four governments in the UK
cash reserves
confidence in business survival
insolvency risk

content.description: This section asks for information about your workforce such as the:

list: percentage, for example, on furlough leave or working from home, or made redundant in the last two weeks
percentage returning from furlough or homeworking
expected redundancies in the next three months

content.description: It also asks about difficulty in retaining or recruiting staff from particular professions.
This section asks for information about the characteristics of your workforce.
We are asking these questions to help understand how workforce characteristics may have changed across different sectors.

questions.question: Recruitment from countries in the EU and EEA

content.description: This section asks information about recruitment of new workers from countries in the EU and EEA, and understanding of the new immigration system that comes into effect on 1 January 2021.
The EEA includes EU countries and Iceland, Liechtenstein and Norway.
We are asking these questions to understand how this new immigration system may affect businesses' recruitment of EU and EEA citizens across different sectors of the economy.

sections.title: Preparedness for the end of the EU transition period

groups.title: Preparedness for the end of the EU transition period

blocks.title: Preparedness for the end of the EU transition period
blocks.description:
This section asks for information about your preparedness for the end of the EU transition period, and any changes to supply chains, as a result.

The transition period is when the UK is no longer a member of the EU but continues to be subject to EU rules and remains a member of the single market and customs union. This period ends on 31 December 2020. For further information about the transition go to GOV.UK/transition

We are asking these questions to understand how the end of the EU transition period may affect trade and supply chain activity in the UK and overseas.

questions.title: Is {{ metadata['ru_name'] }} intending to make changes to supply chains in preparation for the end of the EU transition period?

definitions.title: What we mean by the "end of the EU transition period"

content.description: The transition period is when the UK is no longer a member of the EU but continues to be subject to EU rules and remains a member of the single market and customs union. This ends on 31 December 2020. For further information about the transition go to GOV.UK/transition

questions.title: In which of the following ways is your business planning to change supply chains in preparation for the end of the EU transition period?

definitions.title: What we mean by the "end of the EU transition period"

content.description: The transition period is when the UK is no longer a member of the EU but continues to be subject to EU rules and remains a member of the single market and customs union. This ends on 31 December 2020. For further information about the transition go to GOV.UK/transition

options.label: Using more non-EU suppliers
options.description: As in the rest of the world, excluding EU and UK

options.label: Moving the supply chain away from the short straits crossings
options.value: Moving the supply chain away from the short straits crossings
options.description: "Short straits"are the Euro tunnel and ferry routes between the Port of Dover and Calais, Coquelles or Dunkirk

options.label: Expanding to different modes of freight
options.value: Expanding to different modes of freight
options.description: For example, roll-on/roll-off ferries, lift-on/lift-off flights, air freight or rail freights

questions.title: How prepared are your plans to ensure supply chain continuity for the end of the EU transition period?
Overall, how prepared is your business for the end of the EU transition period?
Which of the following is preventing your business from being fully prepared for the end of the EU transition period?

options.label: Not sure what we need to do to prepare
options.value: Not sure what we need to do to prepare

options.label: No preparation needed as expect a deal to be reached
options.value: No preparation needed as expect a deal to be reached

values: Paused trading but intends to restart in the next two weeks
Paused trading and does not intend to restart in the next two weeks
Paused trading but intends to restart in the next two weeks
Paused trading and does not intend to restart in the next two weeks
None of our sites will temporarily or permanently close

content.description: Grants for specific sectors such as the arts, entertainment, tourism, hospitality, retail, or fisheries provided by the UK or devolved governments.

list: COVID Corporate Financing Facility (CCFF)
Coronavirus Business Interruption Loan Scheme (CBILS or CLBILS)
Bounce Back Loan Scheme (BBLS)
Future Fund
Loans from devolved governments

questions.title: Are you using, or intending to use, either of the following schemes?

options.label: Kickstart Job Scheme for young people
options.value: Kickstart Job Scheme for young people
options.description: Government subsidy to provide six-month work placements for 16 - 24 year olds on Universal Credit

options.label: Coronavirus Job Retention Scheme (CJRS)
options.description: The UK government scheme for furloughed employees

options.label: Not using, or intending to use, either of these schemes
options.value: Not using, or intending to use, either of these schemes

questions.title: How long do you think your business's cash reserves will last?
How much confidence does your business have that it will survive the next three months?

content.description: This is where a business cannot pay its debts when they are due or the business owes more than it owns.

questions.title: How has the coronavirus (COVID-19) pandemic affected your business's risk of insolvency?

blocks.title: Operational performance
blocks.description:
This section asks for information about your workforce such as the:

  • percentage, for example, on furlough leave or working from home, or made redundant in the last two weeks
  • percentage returning from furlough or homeworking
  • expected redundancies in the next three months

It also asks about difficulty in retaining or recruiting staff from particular professions.

questions.title: In the last two weeks, approximately what percentage of {{ metadata['ru_name'] }}'s workforce were:
questions.description:
Your answers need to add up to 100%.

If your workforce did not fall into any of the top five categories, enter "0", then use the "Other" box at the bottom to bring the total to 100%.

Rough estimates are acceptable.

answers.label: On partial or full furlough leave
answers.description: Under the terms of the UK Government's Coronavirus Job Retention Scheme (CJRS)

answers.label: Working at their normal place of work
answers.description: Include those who were normally homeworkers before the pandemic

answers.label: Working from home instead of at their normal place of work
answers.description: Exclude those who were normally homeworkers before the pandemic

answers.label: On sick leave or not working due to coronavirus (COVID-19)  symptoms, self-isolation or quarantine

values: Currently trading and have been for more than the last two weeks
Started trading within the last two weeks after a pause in trading
Paused trading but intends to restart in the next two weeks
Paused trading and does not intend to restart in the next two weeks

questions.title: Of those partially and fully furloughed, what percentage are fully furloughed?
questions.description: "Fully furloughed" refers to workers who are not working any of their normal hours and who you are claiming for under the Coronavirus Job Retention Scheme (CJRS).

content.description: Exclude furloughed staff who are working some hours. These staff are considered "partially furloughed"

definitions.title: How you might answer this question

content.description: If your answer to the previous question was that 80% of your workforce were on partial or full furlough leave, and all of these are on full furlough, then the answer would be 100%. If half of the 80% were on full furlough leave, and the other half partially furloughed, then the answer would be 50%.
A rough estimate is acceptable.

answers.label: Approximate percentage of furloughed staff who are "fully furloughed"
Or select "Not sure"if the percentage is not known or is too difficult to calculate

values: Currently trading and have been for more than the last two weeks
Started trading within the last two weeks after a pause in trading
Paused trading but intends to restart in the next two weeks
Paused trading and does not intend to restart in the next two weeks

questions.title: In the last two weeks, approximately what percentage of your workforce have:

answers.label: Returned from furlough to homeworking, either fully or partially
Returned from furlough to the normal workplace, either fully or partially
Moved from homeworking  to the normal workplace
answers.description: Exclude those who normally worked from home before the pandemic

answers.label: Moved from the normal workplace to homeworking

questions.title: In the next two weeks, approximately what percentage of your workforce will:

answers.label: Return from furlough to homeworking, either fully or partially
Return from furlough to the normal workplace, either fully or partially
Return to the workplace from homeworking
answers.description: Exclude those who normally worked from home before the pandemic

questions.title: Approximately what percentage of your workforce do you expect to be made redundant over the next three months?

answers.label: Approximate percentage of redundancies in the next three months
Or select "Not sure"if the percentage is not known or is too difficult to calculate

questions.title: When do you expect these redundancies to happen?

options.value: Profession(s) relevant but no difference experienced

options.label: These professions are not relevant for this business
options.value: These professions are not relevant for this business

blocks.title: Workforce characteristics
blocks.description:
This section asks for information about the characteristics of your workforce.

We are asking these questions to help understand how workforce characteristics may have changed across different sectors.

questions.title: Since the start of the coronavirus (COVID-19) pandemic, how has the number of workers from within the European Union (EU) at your business changed?

content.description: Exclude those from  the UK (England, Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland)

options.label: Number of workers from within the EU has increased

sections.title: Recruitment from countries in the EU and EEA

groups.title: Recruitment from countries in the EU and EEA

blocks.title: Recruitment from countries in the EU and EEA
blocks.description:
This section asks information about recruitment of new workers from countries in the EU and EEA, and understanding of the new immigration system that comes into effect on 1 January 2021.

The EEA includes EU countries and Iceland, Liechtenstein and Norway.

We are asking these questions to understand how this new immigration system may affect businesses' recruitment of EU and EEA citizens across different sectors of the economy.

questions.title: Does {{ metadata['ru_name'] }} expect to recruit new workers from countries in the EU or EEA in the next 12 months?

content.description: Include:

list: EU or EEA citizens who are living in EU or EEA countries at the time of recruitment and would be coming to the UK to work for your business

content.description: Exclude:

list: those who are living in the UK

questions.title: The immigration system is changing on 1 January 2021 for recruiting employees from the EU or EEA. To what extent do you agree or disagree with this statement: We understand what the new immigration system for recruiting EU or EEA citizens means for our business
Which of the following reasons best describes why your business does not fully understand what the immigration system for recruiting EU or EEA citizens means for the business?

options.label: Not aware that the way to recruit from the EU or EEA is changing
options.value: Not aware that the way to recruit from the EU or EEA is changing

options.label: Not  sure what the business's recruitment plans are so have not looked into it
options.value: Not  sure what the business's recruitment plans are so have not looked into it

options.label: Aware the changes will affect the business, but do not know where to find information
options.value: Aware the changes will affect the business, but do not know where to find information

options.label: Aware the changes will affect the business, but plan on reading guidance at a later date
options.value: Aware the changes will affect the business, but plan on reading guidance at a later date

options.label: Aware the changes will affect the business, but do not plan on reading the guidance
options.value: Aware the changes will affect the business, but do not plan on reading the guidance

options.label: Have read the guidance, but still do not understand what the changes mean for the business
options.value: Have read the guidance, but still do not understand what the changes mean for the business
